Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE MAGNETIC NORTH.
div.p: When Dr. Nansen visited England after his last long sojourn in the Arctic night, he pointed out that he had left nearly four degrees between his "Farthest North" and the Polo itself to be covered by English enterprise. The margin has been twice reduced in the inter­vening years - on the first occasion by the Duke of the Abruzzi's expedition, and on the second through the indomitable persistence of Com­mander Peary. That gallant American sailor has crowned his fifth expedition into the unknown by reaching a latitude of 87 deg. 6 min. N., or within 203 miles of the spot which eye hath not seen, but towards which human wonder stretches with an indefatigable yearn­ing. Commander Perry's success (for in this connection success is still expressed in degrees

of failure) has filled his countrymen with ft very excusable gratification. The Arctic "record" has been achieved by "an American explorer, an American vessel, and an American route," and Englishmen will add their congratulations all the more cordially with the knowledge that the captain of the good ship Roosevelt chose to man her with a Newfoundland crew. The journey, says the "Pall Mall Gazette," has produced additions to the lore of geography of which only a vague impression is yet con­veyed by the brief telegraphic reports of its experience. Land boundaries have apparently been discovered which will set the map-makers to work again, and on the recondite subject of ocean currents Commander Peary will have further additions to make to that important body of facts which was brought home by Dr. of Nansen. The steady progress of the art of ex­ploration is shown by the successful provision against contingencies through which the leader of this latest venture has been able to return ' with the whole membership of his expedition safe and sound. Violent gales interfered with certain of its plans, and one of the supporting parties was rescued only when it had reached the confines of starvation. But Peary, like Nansen, has avoided paying the tribute of life * either to disease or hardship, and has thus done much to weaken the objections which Philis­tine philosophy is too prone to urge against the prosecution of Arctic adventure.

The new "record''-holder of the Far North will have something to say, doubtless, on the possibilities of ultimately reaching the Pole as they seem to be affected by his own exploit. That the boundaries of the "undiscovered country" have been pushed backwards by nearly sixty miles in ten years encourages further persistence in the dream of a cen­tury. On the other hand the obstacles to sledge-travel for more than a certain distance from their base, of which both Peary and Nansen have gained such full experience, inspire obvious doubts as to the remaining two hundred miles being within the compass of possibility. Speculation may turn again towards the balloon or airship plan, and it is noteworthy that the tragedy of Andre's fate has not prevented other projects of a similar kind from being pressed forward. Mr. Wellman proposes to make his start by the aerial route next year, and his scheme would appear to involve the conjoint potentialities of brilliant success and hopeless disaster. With good fortune a dash across the Pole might be conceivably possible where there are no weary weeks to be consum­ed in the labours of painful and arduous transport; at the same time, such a gale as Commander Peary encountered beyond the 85th parallel would presumably mean the end of all things for the aeronaut who fell in with its tender mercies. In any case, the pursuit of the Pole will not cease to enlist the energies of the harder nations and of those peoples which aspire to lead the world either in Empire or knowledge. It is a symptom of degeneracy, whenever such enter­prise comes to be slighted as a mere form of infatuation. Arctic exploration is in no sense a fruitless expenditure of life and energy in the cause of vain glory. It holds the key to many secrets for which Science is clamorous, and its risks are only those which races with the instinct of conquest are ever ready to court for their ideals. The Arctic field is almost neglected just now by Englishmen, though we can happily point to the records of the Discovery and the Scotia at the earth's other extremity in proof that the spirit of Franklin, Parry, McClure and Nares is not extinguished. The great Ice Wars are not the least important test of national vita­lity, anti if the races for the Poles are never to be won, the country which can claim to be foremost in them still holds no empty honour.

div.head: Jerusalem's Progress.
div.p: Advisors from Jerusalem report that the ravines within and without the Gate of Abraham are to be filled up and built over.

div.head: The Pilgrimage
div.p: The Wakfs Administration is making pre­parations to send a medical mission to assist the poor pilgrims during the forthcoming pilgrimage.

div.head: Wakfs Administration.
div.p: The Superior Council of the Wakts Admini­stration will meet in Cairo after the Bevram holidays under the presidency of Adly Pasha Yaghen.

div.head: Transport.
div.p: Some details of the 66th Battery Royal Field Artillery embark at Port Said on the transport Assaye on the 18th inst. for passage to Bombay.

div.head: Antiquities for Turin.
div.p: Professor Schiaparelli has returned to Tnrin with two hundred cases of Egyptian antiquities the contents of which are shortly to be exhibit­ed in the Museum of that town.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: The Silvestre French comedy company will shortly open a series of ten performances at this theatre. The repertoire includes "Cyrano de Bergerac," "Napoleon," "Le Juif Errant," and ' Le Boson."

div.head: Prince's Birthday.
div.p: The 8th birthday of Prince Mohamed Abdel- Moneim, the Heir Apparent was privately celebrated last Tuesday at Montszah Palace, where the Koran ayats were intoned and alms distributed among the poor.

div.head: Tourists.
div.p: The French yacht lie de France arrived at Alexandria from Marseilles this morning with 150 Cook's 'personally-condnoted" French tourists on hoard.The party are on an excursion organised by the "Revue Generate Sciences" of Paris and are leaving Cairo by the 4 25 p m. train to day. After visiting Cairo and Upper Egypt they will rejoin the yacht at Port Said for Jaffa on a visit to the Holy Land.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 10th and 11th November 19 vessels, 7 northward and 12 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr.462,967.49. Of these vessels, 14 were British, 1 German, 2 Norwegian, 1 Dutch, and 1 Russian. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 2,793,241.52. Daring th:s period, 107 vessels transited the Canal, 53 northward and 54 southward bound.

div.head: Zizinla Theatre.
div.p: Mme. Jane Hading, the distinguished French actress, arrived with her company this morn-ing by the French steamer and will make her debat at the Zizinia Theatre this evening with Dumas' comedy "La Princesse Georges," j in which she will take the title rote. This fascinating tbree-act comedy will be pre­ceded by a short " curtain-raiser, '' M. de Ferandy's "Tic a Tic," the two characters of which will be taken by Mile. Sauer and M. Bary. j

div.head: Beyram Holidays.
div.p: We draw the attention of our readers to the facilities afforded by the management of the Tewfik Palace Hotel at Helouan for this year's ; holiday season. The hotel will no doubt, as usual, be the rendez-vous of a great many residents and government officials, who are granted reduced terms. The race-conrsc of the Helouan Sporting Club presents an animated scene every morning and attracts a Urge number of those interested from the Tewfik and other hotels. The golf course and tennis court are in good order. The railway service is now in such excellent working order that nothing on that score remains to be done.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: LEILET EL KADR.

The Khedive arrived at Ras el Tin Palace from Montazab at one o'clock this afternoon. This evening his Highness assists at the Leilet el Kadr( 'Night of Power") ceremony at Abon el Abbas Mosque, which will also be attended by the Governor of Alexandria, the Ulema, and all the native notabilities of Alexandria.
In Cairo the ceremony will be held at the Citadel Mosque, and the Khedive will be represented by his brother, Prince Mohamed Aly.

div.head: DEATH OF LORD CONGLETON.
div.p: A telegram from London announces the death of Lord Congleton, brother of the Hon. Mrs. Henry Hopkinson, wife of Miralai Hop- kinson Bey, which occurred in London yester­day.

Major General Henry Parnell, Lord Congle- ' ton, was the second son of the 3rd Baron, and , grandson of Col. the Hon. William Bligh. He was born in 1839 and succeeded his father in 1896. On leaving Sandhurst he passed into the Buffs and served in the Crimea and Zululand, and from 1895 to 1900 he commanded the Infantry Brigade at Gibraltar; in the latter year he was transferred to Malta, and he retired from the Service two years later. In 1885 he married Elizabeth, daughter of Dugald Dove, of Nutshill, Renfrew.
Lord Congleton is succeeded by his eldest son, the Hon. Henry Bligh Fortescue Parnell, who was born in September 1890.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: During the week ending last Saturday,
seven cases of plague were notified throughout Egypt, viz., 2 at Alexandria, 2 at Port Said, 1 at Suez, 1 in the Samallout district (Minieh), 1 in the Tantah district.

Five deaths took place during the week, three of which occurred outside hospital. Three recoveries are recorded, all of which were European oases treated at Alexandria, and eleven cases remained under treatment.
Since January there have been in all 525 cases of plague, as compared with 265 and 824 during the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respectively.
To day's plague bulletin reports two recov- eries, one of which occured at Alexandria and the other at Samallout, and one admis­sion to hospital at Suez One case at Suez ended fatally yesterday.

div.head: PROVINCIAL MUNICIPALITIES.
div.p: Of late years the provincial municipalities of Egypt have increased in number consider­ably. The latest town to solicit municipal self-government is Emeh, and the question is now being considered by the Ministry of the Interior.

The creation of municipalities in the small towns of the Interior can hardly be considered quite satisfactory as yet In his last report, attached to that of the Ministry of Public Work, Mr. Perry, as in his previous one, criticises un favourably the work done by these municipalities and in connection therewith Sir William Garstin remark-: "I have no doubt whatever that his are just, and that the quality of this work leaves much to be desired. Also, that some of the expenditure may not unfairly be styled waste of morey. Nevertheless, the experiment of local self- government is worth continuing. Time and patient instruction will doubtless improve matters."

div.head: THE DIANA RECOMMISSIONED i * ——
div.p: The cruiser Diana (Captain R. S. Phipps Hornby, C.M.G.) wus paid off on Tuesday last week at Devonport on her return from the Mediterranean Station, for which she was re-

comnnis ioned on the following day. Her crew, which joinedii her in September 1904, was granted thirty-nine days' leave. It will be remembered that it was the Diana which per­fumed naval honours at the opening of Port Sudan last January, and was afterwards sta- tioned off Akaba during the Sinai frontier crisis.

div.head: HIS MANNERS AND MORALS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Dear Sir,—"Al Moayad" has published an interesting reply to my last tetter, the author of which points out that generalisation is nsnally unjust. This I admit again, and again point out that in any community the majority does generalise and mutt generalise. It has not the time, the judgment, or, I fear, the desire to do otherwise.

1 am quite ready to subscribe to "Al Moayad's" opinion that women of all na­tionalities are absolutely safe from molesta­tion in the shops of the principal Arab traders. Indeed, I consider the Moslem merchants of Cairo to be in manners and morals far superior to the classes that are ranked above them. But when ladies who understand Arabic are lucky if they can pass in front of certain cates, etc., situated in the most respectable quar­ters of Cairo, without hearing the most atro­cious comments, every section of the Euro­pean community which cares for the honour of its women and their freedom from mo­lestation will naturally form a low opinion of the whole class to which the ribald imperti- neuta belong. It is, moreover, unfortunately true that those who are the worst offenders in this respect are not ignorant workmen or fellaheen, but men possessed of some means and education, often holders of grades—in fact, corresponding to the upper middle class of European countries.

My critic remarks : "We recognise the excellent character borne by Englishwomen of the upper classes. Cannot their very virtues im­pose respect ?" True, in theory. But in practice self-respecting men are extremely unwilling to take the risk that their wives or sisters will succeed in imposing this respect on all their Moslem visitors. They argue that if men belonging to 'a superior class" of Egyptian can insult respectable women in public - and these insults are unhappily too frequent just now—it is best to avoid close social relations with that class for the present. I grant that in many cases the generalisation is unjust, but it is based upon certain well-known facts. H.H. Princess Nazli Hanem is quoted by Mr. de Guerville as giving a very unfavourable opi­nion of the class to which I refer.

Finally, I should like to point out to my Egyptian critics that the women of the country are extraordinarily free from insult on.the part of Europeans, and that on the principle of reciprocity it is only reasonable that European women should claim and deserve the same immunity.—I am, etc.,
Gael.
Cairo.

div.head: MAHOMEDANS IN INDIA.
div.p: It is stated that it is settled in effect that the Mahomedans of India shall hold an annual gathering to counterbalance in some measure the National Congress of the Hindus. The Aga Khan and the Nawab of Dacca are at the head of this movement, which is one of the most significant that has taken place in India for many years past. A scheme for the con­ference has been prepared by the Nawab of Dacca, and is to be submitted for confirmation to the principal Moslem societies of India. No centre for the holding of'this Mahomedan Congress has yet been selected, but the choice is thought to be between Agra and Lahore. It is hoped that incidentally this conference will be the means every year of raising at least a lakh of rupees for he Mussulman charities.

div.head: MILITARY MOVES.
div.p: Lieut. A.B. Wilkie, 2nd Battalion Royal Sussex Regiment, who arrived at Alexandria from Crete a few days ago, will embark on the transport Sicilia at Port Said on the 16th inst. en route for Peking.
Captain R. S. Bostock, R.A.M.C., will also embark on the Sicilia for duty daring the outward and homeward voyages of that vessel.

div.head: MOTOR BOATS FOR EGYPT.
div.p: In our issue of October 23 we mentioned the fact that Messrs. Dixon Bros, and Hut­chinson, consulting engineers, of Woolston, Southampton, were sending three motor boats, designed and built by the firm, to Alexandria and Caro, and fall particulars of the boats were then given.

These boats will remain in Alexandria for one week and permission to view them can be obtained by applying at the offices of Messrs. James Carroll Wilcocks and Co., 12, rue Mahmoud Pasha el Falaki, the agents of Messrs. Dixon Bros, and Hutchinson for Egypt and the Sudan, to whom all necessary arrange­ments for the reception of the beats have been entrusted. Messrs. Dixon Bros, and Hutchinson intend to sell all three boats if possible in either Alexandria or Cairo, but before selling in Alexandria they reserve the right of running the boats to Cairo and back by the Mahmou- dieh Canal. There are already two sailing yachts designed and built by this firm in the harbour, namely, Isis II. and Banshee II., both of which have been most successful.
The S.S. Adalia, with the two boats on board is expected to arrive-on Friday, the 16th inst.

We must congratulate Messrs. Dixon and Hutchinson on their enterprise and wish them every success in introducing what seems likely to become a most important business in Egypt, the Upper Nite, and the Sudan.

div.head: LACK OF UNITY
div.p: Mahmoud Taher Effendi Haki is the author of an interesting article upon the much dis- cussed question of Egyptian patriotism, in which he attributes its feebleness to the aloof­ness of the classes of the people.

It is not open to doubt, he says, that the Egyptians love their country and devoutly wish her to reach the level of the most pros­perous countries of the world, but that love of country is individual and not public-spirited, owing to the want of cohesion among the classes of the nation.

To show a real and national feeling of patriotism the Egyptians must adapt them­selves to the existing conditions by a wise and moderate policy. They most dearly recognise the obligation under which England has placed them by raising the country to a height of prosperity never attained by their forefathers, whose ambitions were easily satis­fied. But the present-day Egyptian is discon­tented with the progress which has been made possible to him.

When England occupied this country after the rebellion of Arabi the political change which robbed them of their independence was unwelcome. British influence grew year by year and after a quarter of a century the Egyptian nation opposes the occupying Power on one all-important point. The Egyptians assert their capability of assuming their own Government, and, on the other hand, England contends that the time is not yet ripe for them to stand alone.

But neither of these contentions, continues the writer, is beneficial to the people, and a moderate policy must be adopted by both sides. On our side, we should not deceive ourselves with illusive dreams. England could never withdraw white the country is in such a state of torpor. The British authorities, who took so strong a stand when every Euro­pean country was against them, will not retire now when their relations with all the Powers are so amicable.

On the other hand England would have no right in patting the Egyptians under a yoke of injustice, and in turning a deaf ear to their rightful deoMids. Let both nations act in harmony for the country's weal, and with the progress of education the independ­ence of Egypt will be regained.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN
div.p: EGYPT, LIMITED.
The following circular letter has been issued to the shareholders

"Dear Sir (or Madam),—Important infor­mation relating to the trial crops of cotton grown on the newly reclaimed lands of the Corporation has now come to hand, and samples of three of the four varieties of Egypt­ian cotton cultivated this season have been received from Egypt and are open to inspec­tion by shareholders at the offices of the Corporation. These samples comprise : Yano- vitz cotton- Grown, headquarters, Khargeh Oasis, Bore I. ; planted, March 14-March 16, 1906. The bolls are not selected. They are the earliest ripened. This is the first cotton crop from land which was only last year re­claimed. Afifi cotton—Grown, headquarters, Khargeh Oasis, Bore I. ; planted, March 14 March 16, 1906 ; picked, August 14, 1906. The bolls are not selected. They are from those earliest ripened. This is the first cotton crop from land only last year brought under cultivation. Abbassi cotton— Grown, headquarters, Khargeh Oasis, Bore I. The first cotton crop from land brought under cultivation only last summer. Planted, March 14-Maroh 16, 1906 ; picked, August 14, 1906. The bolls are not selected They are from the earliest ripened. (N.B.—The comment is that of the agricultural chemist to the Corporation.)

"Ia view of the fact that cotton is now show­ing a profit of no less than £20 per feddan, the following valuation made in Egypt by cotton experts is significant of the return that may now be anticipated from the cultivation of cotton on a large scale on the reclaimed lands : Yanovitz, P.T. 425-460 per kantar ; Afifi, P.T. 410 per kantar ; Abbassi, P.T. 380 per kantar ; Ashmouni, P.T. 310 per kantar. The average price obtained for cotton in Egypt this year is P.T 350 per kantar. I give below a translation of a communication of interest received from Saad Bey Khalef, a wealthy landowner of Behera, one who is regarded as a judge in matters pertaining to the cultiva­tion of agricultural and cotton lands. He writes : ' I went to the offices of the Corpora­tion of Western Egypt (in Cairo) and saw the samples of cotton, and found them very good, especially the Afifi and Abbassi. Also I saw the samples of wheat and barley, and found them wonderfully good, being the first year's produce, and I congratulate you on the good quality of the lands, as such good crops could not be got the first year except from first-class land." This evidence is confirmatory of the statements respecting the quality of the soil made by the Corporation's manager in the Oases and geological expert, and announced to the shareholders in a circular tetter some time since.- By order of the Board,
"Alfred W. DeEring, Secretary.
"115, Victoria Street, Westminster,
London, S.W.,
' October 27, 1906."

div.head: THE MAHSOUSSEH COAL DEPOT.
div.p: Pera, November 5.

The Ottoman Admiralty Idas designated Lieutenant Dimitri Offend, adjutant to HE. Yank Offend Yoannidis, architect of the Admiralty, to proceed to Port Said to take delivery of the coal stores built by the Suez Canal Company for the Mahsonsseh Line. Lieutenant Dimitraki will he accompanied by Lieutenant Bekir Rashid Effendi, assistant- inspector of the line, who is now on a special mission to Suez.
Turkish Cotton.

The cultivation of cotton having proved a success in several provinces of the Empire, Selim Pasha Melbame. the Minister of Agri­culture, has decided to try Egyptian seed in the vilayets of Adana, Aidin, and Salonica, so as to improve the crop.
Egyptian Notable Decorated.
H.I.M. the Saltan has conferred the G old Medal of the Hedjaz Railway on Ahmed Bey Elfi, an Egyptian notable, who gave a hand­some subscription towards the construction of the Dew line.
Bulgar Cheese for Egypt.

A Bulgarian merchant has informed the Chamber of Commerce of Sofia that there is an excellent opening for Bulgarian cheese (kashkaval) in Egypt, and that this export trade only needs regular sea-communication. The Egyptian market can consume as much as 3,000,000 kilos of kashkaval yearly.
Envoy of the Negus.

M. A. Souroi, private secretary of the Negus, is now in Constantinople, and called on the Hellenic Minister, M. Gryparis. M. Sonroi is visiting the industrial centres of Europe with a view to adapting his experiences to the benefit of Abyssinia. He is leaving this week.
The Bank of Athens.

M. Jean Pesmazoglou, General Manager of the Bank of Athens, who is on his way to Alex­andria, has contributed £1,000, of which half was in the gift of the Bank, towards the fond for rebuilding the Evangheliki School of Smyrna. The Bank is to establish a branch at Smyrna.

div.head: NATIVE PRESS OPINION.
div.p: AGRICULTURE ESSENTIAL TO
PROSPERITY.

"The day when Egyptians abandon agri- fessions for other professions or industries will be the day when the riches of the country will be definitely seized by strangers. We shall become poor and abject, and those of us whom the lawyer's gown has attracted will become a charge on the state, for the new holders of all the true wealth of the country will natnrally prefer to employ their oompatriots. Say as we will that the country needs in­struction, industries and arts, it none the less remains essentially agricultural on account of the extraordinary fertility of its soil and its great climatic and geographical advan­tages

"Our methods of cultivation are antiquated. Now that agriculture as a science has pro­gressed, we should be the first authorities on agriculture in the world, and it is in every way our interest to profit by new discoveries which will enable us to increase the total of our revenues and the yield of our crops. Bat it would seem that European civilisation has progressed too rapidly among us,for the scientific agriculturist has ended by considering him­self an inferior being. Oar young people are devoted to law and medicine, and a lamentable state of affairs has arisen. Longing for a pompons title or ornamental diploma, they sacrifice the most vital interests, and we can only express our genuine concern at the tendency that we note." ("Al Minbar.")

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Hassan, who has been paying a short visit to Caire, returned to Alexandria last night.

The Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., Archdeacon of the Church of England in Egypt, and Mrs. Morley arrived at Alexandria yester­day afternoon by the N.D.L. S.S. Schleswig. They are staying with Canon and Mrs. Alger­non Ward, 5 rue du Musee. His lordship and Mrs. Morley leave for Cairo to-morrow by the noon train.
The Hod. L. M. Iddings, American Diplo­matic Agent, came down to Alexandria yester-day to meet Mrs.and Miss Iddings.and returned with them to Cairo in the afternoon.

Sir Augustus Hemming and Lady Hemming are leaving London for Egypt in a few days. Sir Augustus was in the Colonial Office in Downi ng-street for thirty-six yearsbefore he con­ceived a fancy for administrative work on the spot. About his capability for such duties there could be not the slightest doubt From the routine of the department he had risen to be recognised as one of its ablest men, and had represented England on several boundary and other commissions.

Sir Augustus's first Governorship was that of British Gaiana, but he was not there long when he was sent to Jamaica to succeed Sir Henry Blake, who had gone out to Hong Kong. He was Governor at Jamaica for eight years, retiring in 1904. Among other things, he did much to help West Indian cricket to reach its present position. Although over sixty, he has not altogether lost the prowess he was famed for when he kept wicket for the Gentlemen against the Players.

Vice-Admiral Arthar Charles Burgoyne Bromley, who served in the Abyssinian campain of 1868. is staying at the Continental Hotel, Cairo. He was lieutenant of the Chal­lenger during the survey expedition of 1872-76.
M. Klobukowsky, the new French Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, will take up office on Decem­ber 12.
Signor Guido di Soragna, Italian Consul General at Cairo, left for Italy on Sunday by the S.S. Singapore.
Dr. Henry Goudy, Regins Professor of Civil Law in the University of Oxford, is compelled by illness to spend the winter abroad, and is now on his way to Egypt.

Mr. W. Tindall, who arrived yesterday morning by the Britannia, is staying at Ramleh with Mr. G. B. Alderson, and in a few days will go up to Thebes. Mr. Tindall is one of the best known Anglo Egyptian watercolour artists and intends to take home with him a large number of pictures for exhibition in London. He expects to remain in the country durirg the greater part of the season.

The Messageries S.S. Congo, which arrived from Marseilles to-day, had among her pas­sengers M. de la Booliniere, Comte de Lavizon, Mme de Martino, M. and Mme Poncet, Mme Legrand, Mme Jane Hading, M. and Mme Leblanc, Mme Rodocanachi, M. and Mme Durand.

div.head:
THE FERREIRA FILIBUSTERS.
A DIFFICULT PURSUIT
GERMAN CO-OPERATION SOUGHT

div.p: The Ferreira raid is generally regarded as mere filibustering, which is unsupported.

The police were within 5 miles of the raiders yesterday evening, and are now hotly pursuing them. The country is sandy and water is scarce. The chase is most difficult. The raiders, who are moving due east, have succeeded in obtaining several recruits. The wounded troop­ers are dead. Colonel Lukin will arrive in Prieska to morrow and assume command of the operations.
Later,

The Governor of the Cape has telegraphed to the German Governor asking him to co­operate in capturing the free hooters should they re-cross the border, with a view to extra­dition on the charges of theft and murder. R.)

div.head:
TRANSVAAL SELF GOVERNMENT.
ISSUE OF LETTERS PATENT,

div.p: House of Commons.-Sir Henry Campbell- Bannorman stated that he expected that letters-patent establishing the self-government of the Transvaal would be issued during the present month. (Peuter)

div.head:
THE MOROCCO QUESTION,
PRANCE NOT ANXIOUS.

div.p: M. Pichon, on being interviewed,stated that the Morocco question did not cause any anxiety. (Haxas)

div.head:
MOSCOW BOMB OUTRAGE.
ATTEMPT ON THE MAYOR.

div.p: A bomb was thrown to-day in Moscow in the fashionable thoroughfare of Tverskaja at M. Reinbort, Mayor of the city. He escaped un­hurt. A policeman shot the author of the gutrage dead. (Reuter)
A bomb was thrown at the Prefect Reinbach, who was not touched, and shot his aggressor dead with a revolver. (Havas)
The "Times" learns from Peking that the Waiwapu ft representative of the British Chinese Corporation have signed an agreement for the construction cf the Canton to Kaulnng railway. {Reuter)
The King and Queen of Norway arrived at Portsmouth and proceeded to Windson on a State visit. (Reuter)
The Chamber of Deputies has decided to go on with the discussion of the clauses of the electoral law. (Haxas)

Mr. W. St. Chad Boscawen writes to the Globe" as follows :—

The great work of exploration, now drawing ear completion, on which the Egypt Explora- ion Fund have been engaged at Deirel- lahari, naturally draws attention to the men to whom we owe the beantiful edifices of the Temples of the Twelfth and Eighteenth Dynasties. The decoration of the first temple, hat of Mentu-hetep III., we may certainly assign to Mertiscn, who was a skilled artist rafts man, and who appears, from his work recently exhibited in London, to have been the riginator of the style of high coloured relief which proved so effective in the adornment if the older Hathor Temple. The second and srender temple, built by the remarkable Queen Hatshepsut, was certainly the work of Senmut -one of the most remarkable of the many artists and statesmen of the Theban Court, Hatshepsut seems to have bad the power of lading men of talent even of obscure origin, and raising them to high positions in the State. Sermut appears to have been one of these proteges for it is stated on his statue found in the temple of Mut at Thebes by Messrs. Benson and Gourlay, that he was a nan "whose ancestors were not found in writing that is, were not members of the Theban aristocracy. Beside this statue there is another in Berlin, and bis tomb was found bv Dr. Steindorf at: Abd el Gurneh in 1895. Prom these records it is possible to compile a Fairly complete biography of this remarkable man. He first appears as having been sent to the granite quarries at Assouan to superintend the jutting of two great obelisks for the Queen, which were erected at Karnak, an f one of which still remains in situ. It was, however, is a builder end architect that he was most celebrated, He is styled 'the architect of all the works of the Queen in Karnak, Erment, of Deir-el-Bahari, and of the Theban temple Mut where his statue was found, He says that he was great in establishing the monu­ments of the mistress of the twolands, and in erecting all works." He was also overseer and superintendent of all temples—that is, architect to the ecclesiastical commissioners of the period.

He gained the complete confidence of his royal mistress, for he says "that I filled the heart of the Queen daily. I was upright, and the mistress of two lands was pleased with that which came forth from my mouth " That the Queen did so favour him is shown by the statue being erected by order of the Queen, 'or it bears the inscription "Presented by order of the Queen, so that his memory might be good before the people for all time." Like Rubens, of whom it is said, ' S'amu. at d'etre ambassadeur," Senmut held high offices of Rate. He is called "Great one of the great ones," and as such was a species of Prime Minister, for all affairs were reported to me, and I directed the North and South." He was also "Royal Chancellor &nd Keeper of the King's Seal." Of course, like most Egyptian officials, he had also priestly offices, He was chief priest of t he Mortuary Temple of Alah- mes, the founder of the dynasty, and chief over the Secrets of the Great House and Temple of Amen in Karnak. He was also keener of the store houses and the gardens of Amen, the latter being those planted by the Queen with strange plants from the Holyland of Punt. 3nch is the man whom the great Queen raised from obscurity to greatnes', and whose name will survive to all time jn his great work—'he Temple of Deir el-Bahau, the monument of Sir Christopher Wren is found in St. Paul's itself. This history of so great an artist is another proof of the extent to which indivi­duality was recognised in Egypt, and not, as in Assyria, all merged in the King's person,

div.head: VOLUNTEER SURPRISE.
div.p: Orders have been received at headquarters of the Volunteer battalions of the Manchester Regiment and the Lancashire Fusiliers, and of the Manchester Volunteer Engineers and the Manchester Volunteer Artillery, directing the commanding officers to place all non-commis­sioned officers on the staffs under them under four months' notice of dismissal. This is taken as meaning that the staff sergeants and instructors, who are now adding to their pen­sions by work in Volunteer battalions, are to make room for the sergeants of the disbanded line battalions of the Manchester Regiment and the Lancashire Fat-Piers. Great indigna­tion, says the Manchester correspondent of the "Daily Telegrapb," is felt in local Volun­teer circles. In one battalion four men will be affected and in others nine, and as there are six of the Manchester Regiment and three of the Fusiliers, a considerable number of men will be thrown back on their pensions alone, which, in many cases, will reduce them to poverty and the ranks of the unemployed.

div.head: AFRICA'S MAIDEN COMMISSION.
div.p: The new battleship Africa, whose first keel plate was laid at Chatham Dockyard on Jan. 7th,1904,hoisted her pennant at that establish merit last week for her maiden commission. The Africa, which is a powerful battleship of the King Edward VII. class, built with a displacement of 16,350 tons,will be manned by the late nucleus crew of the Ramillies, battle- ship, borgbt up to full strength by ratings from the Medway depot, and will join the At antic Fleet Captain H. R. Robiusor, lately commanding the armoured cruiser Aboukin, will commission her.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The command of the 1st Battalion Cold­stream Guards, from which Colonel G. Pley- dell-Bouverie retired, has been given to Major the Hon. William

Lambton, D.S.O., C.M.G , (brother of the Earl of Durham), second in command of the 2nd Battalion. Lieutenant- Colonel La mb ton joined the Coldstreamers in February, 1884, was aide de-camp to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, 1895 97, employed with the Egyptian Army, 1897 98, and Military Secretary to Lord Milner in South Africa, 1900 04. Whilst in Egypt he went through the expedition to Khartoum, the battles of the Atbara and Omdurman (mentioned in despat­ches, DSO., Egyptian melal with clasp, Brit­ish medal), and with the Guards he shared in Methuen's operations for the relief of Kimber­ley-Belmont, Enslin, Mq Ider River, Magers- fontien—and the subsequent operations in the Transvaal and Orange River Colony (mention ed in despatches, Queen's medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps).

The command of the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Belfast, which was vacat­ed by Colonel G. M. Mackenzie on completion of the usual four years at its head, was taken up to-day by Lieutenant Colonel Charles J. L. Davidson, D.S.O., from second in command of the 2nd Battalion at Cairo. The new chief of the gallant oil 27th came under the opera­tion of the age roles a few weeks ago, but bis claims were too strong to be overruled by a few weeks' over age, and the point was waived by the Army Council. Lieutenant Colonel David|- son has realised the ambition of his military career to ride at the head of the 27th Inniskillings. The representative of an old Londonderry family, he joined the 27th Innia- killings, when it wore that number, in August, 1879, was promoted captain in 1888, was ad­jutant of the 4th Battalion (Royal Tyrone Fusiliers) 1892-97, promoted major in 1899, just before having for the front, and since this time four years was second in command of the 2nd Battalion. He accompanied the 1st Battalion from Mullinger to the front, and was with it at the actions of Oolenso, Spion Rop, Vaal Krantz, Tqgela Height", Pieter's Hill, where he was badly wounded; the opera­tions east of Pretoria, including the actions of Belfast, Lydenburg, etc., and the operations in Orange River Colony and Cape Colony (mentioed in despatches twice, D. S. 0., Queen-s medal with five clasps, King's medal with two clasps At Pieter's Hill, in that last awful charge, he was shot down, and beside him, mortally woundedj fell his brave young brother in-l&w, Lieutenant Stuart, son of the late Major 8tuart, Omagh. The announcement of Lieutenant Colonel Davidson's appointment has given the liveliest satisfaction in the old 27th Iniskillings. .

. The vacant company in the King's Royal Rifle Corps has been filled by the promotion of Lieutenant A.F.C. Maolachlan, D.S.O., who has been serving latterly with the 3rd Battalion at Aldershot. Captain Maolaohlan gets bis step at seven years' service. He earned his decoration in the South African War on the Way to Ladysmith (mentioned thrice in des­patches, D,S.O., Queen's medal with four clasps, King's medal with two clasps) in the course of which he was wounded.

The S.S. Sicilia left Southampton to-day with a large number of troops on board, chiefly drafts for Gibraltar, Malta, Caylon, Singapore, Hong Kong, and North China. She is due at Port Said on the 16th inst.

The vacant majority has gone to Captain and Brevet Major J. McC. Steele, who is now employed as Brigade Major of the Brigade of Guards. Second Lieutenant R.A. Arkwright, of the 3rd Battalion at Cairo, has been promoted l'eutenant. He got his commission in March, 1904.

The tremendous defeat which the Radioal- Laboor-Socialist candidates have just received in London, where they have been practically wiped out, in the Municipal elections, and the very heavy losses the same combination have received all over England, reflects public opi­nion on the truckling to which the present Government has subjected itself, in obedience to the Laboar-Radioal tail, which wags the body. Public opinion has been thoroughly aroused to the fact that the schemes for the reduction of the army and navy are mena­cing the very existence of the Empire, and if a general election came on in the near future there is not the slightest doubt but that the Conservatives would return to power with a big majority.

The first-class cruiser Baoohaute has been selected to carry the flag of Sir H. Barry, the new commander of the Third Cruiser Squadron in the Mediterranean. The flagship will leave Portsmouth about the 22nd just, and at Malta the crew of the Leviathian, which has carried the flag for some time, will be transferred to her. The latter will then return horne. The Bicchante carried the flag of the late Pear Admiral Sir Baldwin Walker when he com­manded the Cruiser Sqoadron in the Mediter ranean, 1902 05.
The survey ship Merlin, Captain J. F. Parry, which has just left England for the China Station, Will do some much needed survey work in the Red Sea whilst on the passage to her station.

div.head: PORT SAID ENGINE WORKS.
div.p: Dowrie Co., Port Said, have on hand a Large quantity of boilers, engines, lathes, pumps, fan blasts, etc., etc.; also a large stock of cast Iron, about 20,000 second hand pipes spigot and faucet type in good condition 6 1/2 and 8"diameter. Owing to removal of Works these must be cleared. Offers at from Pcs. 60 per ton upwards (according to the article) will, therefore be considered if received in time. Exceptional opportunity. Boilers are fully ser­viceable for steaming or at the price would make excellent storage tanks

div.head: Important Notice.
div.p: The attention of the public is drawn to the
notice published by the Alexandria Munici­pality a month ago on the subject of the valuation of house property of which the first valuation was made eight years ago.

The Municipality particularly draws the attention of the proprietors to the regulation by which they are required to advise the Administration of all new constructions, addi­tions, or curtailments to their property before the fifteenth instant, under penalty of a double fine.
Administrator (Signed) W. P. Chataway.
Alexandria, November 12. 28839 3 1

div.head: Egyptian State Railways,
div.p: NOTICE.

The Egyptian State Railways Administration have the honour to inform the Public that, from Thursday, 1st November, a dining car will be attached to No. 6 train leaving Luxor for Shallal at 10.30 a.m., and to No. 5 train leaving Shallal for Luxor at 9.40 a.m., on the following days :
From Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.
From Shallal every Wednesday, Friday and Monday.
Cairo, 1st November, 1906.
G. B. Macauley,
28829-2-2 General Manager.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.
